Key Match Events: Kiké Hernández started the comeback with a two-run homer in the seventh inning, trimming a 5-1 deficit in half.
Freddie Freeman cashed Ohtani’s steal of second base with an RBI single, making it 5-4.
Shohei Ohtani hit his 53rd home run of the season in the eighth inning.
Mookie Betts completed the comeback, launching a two-strike, 100.6 mph sinker into the left-field pavilion for his second career walk-off home run, and first with the Dodgers.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers were trailing and in danger of dropping two of three to the National League West’s worst team, the Colorado Rockies.
The Padres were in the process of completing a series sweep over the historically bad Chicago White Sox, which caught Betts' eye on the out-of-town scoreboard.
Manager Dave Roberts emphasized the importance of strong bullpen performance.
The Dodgers needed to win a game to keep their division lead over the Padres.
Post-Match Reflections: Mookie Betts expressed that he didn’t mean to look at the scoreboard but acknowledged the urgency of the situation.
Manager Dave Roberts said, 'That, felt like two wins.'
Betts said, 'Shohei starts it off with a homer there to give us some energy. And fortunately I was able to put a good swing on it.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: Yoshinobu Yamamoto struggled through a four-run, three-inning start, failing to command the ball (three walks) or limit contact (four hits).
The Dodgers' offense squandered a flurry of early opportunities, leaving 11 of their 13 baserunners stranded.
DODGERS pitcher Anthony Banda wants to make clear how he broke his hand.
